X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=191742632; y=aCTcwVsQn68FyU1ifbSqEjYZpGwFTQaXJxG_bXLAXlG3Rc88bBOD
X-Yahoo-Profile: maitrikaruna

John

I have to agree with Jeff here...my instincts tell me that NEAT 
should be highly amenable to finding optimum network structures that 
have desired results...

I will say though that this is a thorny problem.  figuring out how 
to properly handle firing sequences, feedback, etc will be 
challenging.  ideally you want it to eventually find a network where 
the output can actually generate the input.  

They have shown that we have one neuron to identify a particular 
face.  That is the neuron at the top of the hierarchy.  If this is 
the "elvis" neuron, even when I say "elvis" you get a picture of 
Elvis in your head.  This is the feedback from that one neuron back 
to the outputs simulating the visual input IMO.  This feedback also 
allows us to fill in missing pieces...i.e.- i show you a picture of 
half of elvis' face, your brain fills in the rest.

If a NEAT + Hawkins approach works in something like visual 
recognition, this would be groundbreaking for sure.  Mainly because 
if it works there it should work in other seneory domains as well. 

I also think it might be necessary to seed NEAT with a somewhat more 
complex beginning structure here because I believe a certain minimum 
of links/nodes both recurrent and otherwise will be necessary as a 
baseline...then let NEAT expand from there. 

Now if I just had the time to do it...

Best,
Kevin


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Jeff Haynes" <jeff@d...> wrote:
> 
> > > I am moving towards something much more complex.  I would like 
to
> > > try and implement NEAT+Hawkins(On Intelligence) ideas on how 
the
> > > brain works.  This requires more complex structures that 
allow, for
> > > instance, for recurrent connections back to *input* nodes.
> > 
> > Yes, outputs are inputs.  It's all a big loop.  But it's more 
than
> > just that...  When the 'expected' input (which is an output of an
> > 'expectation' circuit) doesn't match the input, you get one 
result. 
> > When it does, you get another.  But that kind of thing is VERY
> > different than NEAT.
> > 
> 
> Well, NEAT doesn't address this specifically but I'm not sure what 
you're
> saying here.  It's certainly "handled" by NEAT as well as anything 
else
> (seemingly better in some cases).
> 
> > 
> > > there is also a strong temporal aspect to this according to
> > > hawkins.  incorporating both the feedback and temporal aspects 
into
> > > a net raises the level of complexity quite a bit.  Hawkins 
team has
> > > implemented a fixed structure hierarchy that is not really a 
NN.  It
> > > uses bayesian probabilities throughout the feedback mechanism.
> > > Their early tests show some real promise in invariant visual
> > > recognition...but I feel their structure is too constrained and
> > > would like to see if NEAT can be applied with his concepts
> > > incorporated.  It may not work or may be too complex...I 
dunno...
> > 
> > I don't think NEAT is what you want.  I think you want a dynamic
> > network that grows during the life of the organism.  Which means 
you
> > need a set of rules governing that growth.  Evolution might best 
be
> > applied to those rules, rather than to the structure itself.
> > 
> 
> I disagree.  I think this is exactly the sort of thing NEAT would 
excel at. 
> Any time you have recurrency, there are "temporal aspects" but 
it's just a
> higher order of topology.  In fact, NEAT is evolving rules for 
building
> structure, just not at the same level you're suggesting here (a la 
cellular
> automata).  Growth over the life of the organism is interesting 
and something
> I'm not experienced with.  When our brains "grow" is that out of 
necessity or
> opportunity?
> 
> As for Bayesian networks, I believe it's just another spin on the 
same
> problem.  Someone correct me if I'm wrong, but I believe anything 
that can be
> done by a bayesian network can in theory be done with a NN.
> 
> Regards,
> 
> jeff
